question: The AWR can be used on the ground provided: 1. The aircraft is clear of personnel, buildings and vehicles. 2. The conical beam is selected. 3. Maximum up tilt is selected. 4. The AWR must never be operated on the ground.
explanation:
The operation of airborne weather radar on the ground imposes the following risks:

  1. Risk of injury to personnel in the vicinity.

  2. Risk of ignition of fuel vapours in the vicinity.

  3. Risk to damage to AWR caused by the very strong returns that will be received from reflective objects in the vicinity.

But if there is a known risk of thunderstorms and turbulence in the climb out area it is a sensible precaution to test the AWR before take-off. To minimise these risks the ground testing of AWR is permitted, but it must be carried out in accordance with specific health and safety regulations. Of the options listed in this question options 1, 2 and 3 are those most likely to be included in such regulations.

question: An aircraft flying at 25 00 feet is equipped with AWR. The beam width is 5 degrees. With the radar tilted 3.5 degrees up, the radar is showing top of a cloud return at 105 nm. The approximate height of the cloud is.
explanation:
This type of question is best solved by calculating the height of the cloud top relative to the aircraft then adding this to the aircraft height. Although the question does not specifically state this, assume that the top of the cloud is just visible at the bottom of the radar screen.

  • The beam is 5 degrees wide so it extends 2.5 degrees above and below its centreline.

  • So with the centreline of the beam tilted 3.5 degrees up the bottom of the beam will be tilted at an angle of 3.5 degrees – 2.5 degrees = 1 degrees up.

The 1 in 60 rule as applied to this type of question states that:
Height above aircraft in nm = (angle in degrees × distance to cloud in nm) / 60

Inserting the data provided in the question gives:
Height above aircraft in nm = (1 degrees × 105 nm) / 60 = 1.75 nm.

Multiplying the 1.75 nm by 6080 ft/nm converts this into 10640 feet.

So the cloud top is 10640 feet above the aircraft.

Adding this to the aircraft height gives a cloud height of
10640 ft + 25000 ft = 35640 ft.
The closest option to this is 35600 ft.
subject: Radio Navigation

question: The radar in an aircraft at FL370 detects a cloud at 60 nm. The cloud disappears when the tilt is selected to 2° UP. If the beamwidth of the radar is 6°, at what altitude are the tops of the clouds?
explanation:
Height of Cloud above or below the aircraft (ft) = Range in NM x (Tilt – 1/2 Beam Width) x 100

Tilt 2 degree up means that the center of the beam is 2° up.

Since the beam has a width i.e. 6° degrees, the bottom of the beam is below the horizon.

Anyhow, just use the formula and preserve the sign of the angles.

If the answer is a minus figure then the cloud tops are below the aircraft, if plus then they are above.

Height of Cloud above or below the aircraft (ft) = Range in NM x (Tilt – 1/2 Beam Width) x 100

=60 x (2° – 3°) x 100

= -6000 ft

So the cloud tops are at 37,000 – 6000 = 31,000 ft.
subject: Radio Navigation
